thread.title: Google making it easier to shop online
thread.title_full: Google making it easier to shop online

author: Catie Low
title: Google making it easier to shop online
text:
Google is making it easier to shop on your smartphone, by embedding a "buy" button in the advertisements that feature at the top of search results.
This latest offering from the tech giant will potentially open a new sales channel for nimble Australian retailers but market watchers warn its focus on price will only sharpen price competition.
The catch for Australian retailers was that to reap the benefits of this new "touch point" they would need to capture and analyse who was using it and how, Telsyte senior analyst Steven Noble said.
"Data is at the centre of this ... they [retailers] need to measure specifically what is happening with Google shopping and learn quickly from it," Mr Noble said.
Advertisement "Google will now open up as an important third-party channel in the same way that eBay already is."
Retailers that were slow to adapt would lose traction with this touch point and potentially sales, he said.
There was also a risk that the more direct path from search to sale could reduce customer browsing on retail sites and as a result lead to a lower number of purchases from any one site.
Purchases on Google will also use browser history to show if the price of product has fallen, as well as provide rating data and the availability of a product in nearby stores.
But it does nothing to address one of the key barriers to online shopping in Australia, which is the lag between buying and receiving, says David Thomas, head of Australian consumer research at CLSA.
Australian retailers were still struggling to make the economics right of the "last mile" work, Mr Thomas said.
"In the UK and the US they have sophisticated distribution systems and as a result the cost is lower and the service provision is significantly better," he said.
"Here you can be waiting five days plus for a retailer to execute on online shopping.
"Retailers here have been loath to attack [online] aggressively or put the capital in place because it's hard to get the economics to stack up."
Google's new shopping channel will also provide price on products a shopper has researched in the past and will use browser history to show if the price has dropped.
Google is testing Purchases on Google with a group of retailers in the US.
